title: Adding your own Variables
text: Find relevant variables ONS LFS User guidance. Add function . Load function, pass argument lfs_compile. example, add marital status: add variable changes time, use pick_var. example, degree class DEGCLS7 2007 onwards, DEGCLS . code imports factor (retaining SPSS labels), calls new column DEGREE_CLASS.
code: user_extra_mappings <- function(lfs_file_column_names) {    custom_variables <- tibble::tribble(     ~lfs_name,       ~new_name,     ~type,     "MARSEX6", "SEX_AND_MARITAL_STATUS", "factor"     )    return(custom_variables) }  lfs_compile("your_lfs_rds_directory", extra_mappings = user_extra_mappings) user_extra_mappings <- function(lfs_file_column_names) {    # This will pick DEGCLS7 if it exists in the quarterly file,   # if not then DEGCLS, otherwise it'll return NA.   degree_class <- pick_var(c("DEGCLS7", "DEGCLS"), lfs_file_column_names)    custom_variables <- tibble::tribble(     ~lfs_name,       ~new_name,     ~type,     "MARSEX6", "SEX_AND_MARITAL_STATUS", "factor",     degree_class, "DEGREE_CLASS", "factor"     )    return(custom_variables) }  lfs_compile("your_lfs_rds_directory", extra_mappings = user_extra_mappings)

title: Code for replicating some ONS Publications
code: lfs <- lfs_load()    earn04 <- lfs %>%     dplyr::filter(FTPTWK == "Full-time") %>%     lfs_summarise_salary(QUARTER) %>%     dplyr::select(QUARTER, mean_weekly_pay, median_weekly_pay)

title: Code for replicating some ONS Publications
code: earn06 <- lfs %>%     dplyr::filter(FTPTWK == "Full-time") %>%     dplyr::filter(!is.na(OCCUPATION_MAJOR)) %>%     lfs_summarise_salary(QUARTER, OCCUPATION_MAJOR) %>%     tidyr::pivot_wider(       id_cols = QUARTER,       names_from = OCCUPATION_MAJOR,       values_from = "mean_weekly_pay"     )

title: Code for replicating some ONS Publications
code: earn07 <- lfs %>%     dplyr::filter(YEAR > 2009) %>%     dplyr::filter(!is.na(INDUSTRY)) %>%     dplyr::mutate(GROUPED_INDUSTRY = dplyr::case_when(       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) == "A" ~ "A",       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% c("B", "D", "E") ~ "BDE",       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% "C" ~ "C",       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% "F" ~ "F",       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% "G" ~ "G",       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% "H" ~ "H",       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% "I" ~ "I",       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% "J" ~ "J",       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% c("K", "L") ~ "KL",       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% "M" ~ "M",       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% "N" ~ "N",       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% "O" ~ "O",       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% "P" ~ "P",       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% "Q" ~ "Q",       substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% c("R", "S", "T") ~ "RST"       # substr(INDUSTRY, 1, 1) %in% "U" ~ "U"     )) %>%     dplyr::filter(!is.na(GROUPED_INDUSTRY)) %>%     dplyr::filter(FTPTWK == "Full-time") %>%     lfs_summarise_salary(QUARTER, GROUPED_INDUSTRY) %>%     tidyr::pivot_wider(       id_cols = QUARTER,       names_from = GROUPED_INDUSTRY,       values_from = "mean_weekly_pay"     )

title: Code for replicating some ONS Publications
text: ONS Publication Accurate 1995 onwards, also replicates sex splits adding SEX grouping variable.
code: unem01 <- lfs %>%     dplyr::filter(YEAR > 1995) %>%     lfs_summarise_unemployment(QUARTER) %>%     dplyr::select(QUARTER, unemployed_percentage) %>%     dplyr::mutate(unemployed_percentage = unemployed_percentage * 100) %>%     dplyr::filter(!is.na(unemployed_percentage))

title: Code for replicating some ONS Publications
code: hour01 <- lfs %>%     dplyr::mutate(FT = !FTPTWK == "Full-time") %>%     lfs_summarise_hours(QUARTER, FT) %>%     tidyr::pivot_wider(       id_cols = QUARTER,       names_from = FT,       values_from = hours     )

title: Authors and Citation
Authors and Citation
text: Klimowicz W (2025). tidylfs: Tools analysing ONS Labour Force Survey. R package version 0.0.3, https://wklimowicz.github.io/tidylfs/, https://github.com/wklimowicz/tidylfs.
code: @Manual{,   title = {tidylfs: Tools for analysing the ONS Labour Force Survey},   author = {Wojtek Klimowicz},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.3,     https://wklimowicz.github.io/tidylfs/},   url = {https://github.com/wklimowicz/tidylfs}, }

title: Tools for analysing the ONS Labour Force Survey
text: can install development version tidylfs GitHub :

title: Tools for analysing the ONS Labour Force Survey
text: Copy LFS .sav files directory (example lfs_data_folder). look like : can run: reproduce official ONS publications, Unemployent UNEM01 NSA Salary occupation EARN06 Extending easy: Unemployment quarter, sex, age category information ONS variables, see LFS Guidance. variables included default :
code: . └── lfs_data_folder/     ├── 1992 Q1.sav     ├── 1992 Q2.sav     ├── ...     └── 2020 Q2.sav library(tidylfs)  # Converts `.sav` files to `.Rds` files, to save # space and for quicker loading lfs_convert(lfs_directory = "lfs_data_folder/",             output_directory = "lfs_rds_folder/")  # Compiles into one file. lfs <- lfs_compile(lfs_directory = "lfs_rds_folder/") lfs %>%     lfs_summarise_unemployment(QUARTER) lfs %>%     dplyr::filter(       !is.na(OCCUPATION_MAJOR), # Filter out NA's       FTPTWK == "Full-time" # Take only full-time employees     ) %>%     lfs_summarise_salary(QUARTER, OCCUPATION_MAJOR) lfs %>%   lfs_summarise_unemployment(QUARTER, SEX, AGES)

what: Using the data across multiple projects
title: Tools for analysing the ONS Labour Force Survey
text: avoid storing multiple copies compiled dataset, can set DATA_DIRECTORY environment variable compiling. can done system .Rprofile: compiling dataset include save_to_folder option TRUE: compiled dataset saved directory fst file, can load anywhere using command:
code: Sys.setenv(DATA_DIRECTORY = "path/to/folder") lfs_compile(lfs_directory = "lfs_rds_folder/", save_to_folder = TRUE) lfs <- lfs_load(data.table = FALSE)

title: Load APS Data — aps_load
text: works DATA_DIRECTORY environment variable set folder. can either manually save aps_data.fst , optionally saved compilation DATA_DIRECTORY variable present running lfs_compile(..., aps = TRUE)

Load APS Data — aps_load
Compile to single data.frame — lfs_compile
text: Compiles seperate fst files one, picking relevant columns

title: Compile to single data.frame — lfs_compile
code: lfs_compile(   lfs_directory,   filter_years = NULL,   extra_mappings = NULL,   save_to_folder = FALSE,   save_variables_report = TRUE,   aps = FALSE )

title: Compile to single data.frame — lfs_compile
text: lfs_directory Path directory LFS files filter_years Vector years filter extra_mappings Either NULL (use default) file custom mapping function. See vignette("Adding_Variables", package = "tidylfs") save_to_folder TRUE, save DATA_DIRECTORY environment variable present save_variables_report Save csv list picked variables? aps Annual Population Survey flag, files called eg. "APS 2012.sav"

title: Compile to single data.frame — lfs_compile

title: Convert files to Rds for faster compiling in future — lfs_convert
text: lfs_directory Directory raw LFS files output_directory Target directory save Rds files filter_files Limit certain files, using named vector incremental convert files exist output directory
